Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a living document. As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Sun World International has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 

1.1	SUN WORLD INTERNATIONAL, RISK & PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM 

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Sun World International has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Ammonia Refrigeration |	Ammonia	| 32,000 lb

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illnesses and avoid physical property damage.

Sun World International has an exemplary safety record, one that we are quite proud of. Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1.	Prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP oblig

ations as well
2.	Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general Sun World International business practices
3.	Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary Sun World International employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees protect themselves and our neighbors.

1.2	PROCESS DESCRIPTION

Sun World International operates a commercial storage facility which utilizes an ammonia refrigeration system for cooling. The ammonia system provides refrigeration capacity to nine (9) storage rooms, three (3) precool rooms, several hallway units, and a hydrocooler.

The pumped overfeed system for the all the rooms and hallway units operate as follows:  high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped through a series of two liquid feed solenoid valves, an expansion valve, and into a liquid recirculator.  From there, low pressure liquid is pumped to each degreening room, where it passes through a solenoid valve, hand expansion valve and into evaporator coils.  Low temperature liquid circulates through the evaporator coils.  Low pressure and temperature gas and overfeed liquid passes through an isolation valve and is returned to the liquid recirculator.  The residual liquid is separated from the gas in the accumulator and the suction gas is piped to two screw compressors which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas.  The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to the high pressure receiver.

The Hydrocooler utilizes flooded system. The flooded portion of the system operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to the hydrocooler where it passes through an expansion valve into a low pressure accumulator vessel.  Low temperature liquid circulates by thermal c

onvection through the hydrocooler coils.  Low pressure and temperature gas collects in the accumulator vessel, and passes through a pressure regulator into a suction line. The suction line returns the vapor to the liquid recirculator located in the engine room, which separates any residual liquid from the gas. The gas is piped to the compressors which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas.  The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to the high pressure receiver.

The facility was designed and installed by professional refrigeration engineers in accordance with industry standards at the time.  It was also built in compliance with the Uniform Mechanical Code and Uniform Building Code applicable at the time of construction. The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and safety relief valves which vent ammonia gas to the atmosphere if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point. Lastly, the system has an emergency dump box that contains switches and valves to turn off equipment and vent ammonia if necessary.
  
The ammonia systems at consist of vessels which are interconnected, or which are co-located such that a release of ammonia could impact the ability to operate vessels that are not directly connected.  Therefore, each system is treated as a single process.

1.3	GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE & CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

1.3.1	GENERAL 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

Sun World International has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in the body of the program. 

1.3.2	ANHYDROUS AMMONIA

The ammonia refrigeration process at the Sun World International facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. The ammonia process contains a total charge of approximately 30,000lbs. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. e will respond minimally to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 

Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.

1.6	PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Our company has an outstanding safety record, one that we are quite proud of. Many policies and procedures have been implemented to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Sun World International continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Sun World International's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Sun World International's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

Sun World International has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Sun World International has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation. A copy of Resource Compliance's service agreement has been included in this program with the support material.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 

1.3.3	SULFUR-DIOXIDE

The sulfur-dioxide process at the Sun World International facility is an integral part of overall business and lasts for approximately five months out of the year. The sulfur-dioxide process contains multiple cylinders with a maximum inventory of 900lbs. It is extremely important that these areas and associated injection processes are maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Sun World International is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of exposure to sulfur-dioxide.

Our personnel also monitor the sulfur-dioxide fumigation process and keep an active log of all associated procedures and transactions. In addition, the process is checked frequently during the season by the outside contractor that supplies the SO2 cylinders. The contractor also assists in performing the annual mechanical integrity review of our process equipment. 

1.4	FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Sun World International has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.
